trans-unit.source: DataStax Enterprise on Ubuntu with a Resource Manager Template
trans-unit.target: DataStax Enterprise on Ubuntu with a Resource Manager Template

trans-unit.source: Learn to easily deploy a new DataStax Enterprise cluster on Ubuntu VMs using Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI and a Resource Manager template
trans-unit.target: Learn to easily deploy a new DataStax Enterprise cluster on Ubuntu VMs using Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI and a Resource Manager template

trans-unit.source: DataStax is a recognized industry leader in developing and delivering solutions based on Apache Cassandra™ - the commercially-supported, enterprise-ready NoSQL distributed database technology that is widely-acknowledged as agile, always-on, and predictably scalable to any size.
trans-unit.target: DataStax is a recognized industry leader in developing and delivering solutions based on Apache Cassandra™ - the commercially-supported, enterprise-ready NoSQL distributed database technology that is widely-acknowledged as agile, always-on, and predictably scalable to any size.

trans-unit.source: DataStax offers both the Enterprise (DSE) and Community (DSC) flavors.
trans-unit.target: DataStax offers both the Enterprise (DSE) and Community (DSC) flavors.

trans-unit.source: In addition to what the Community edition provides, Datastax Enterprise is Production-certified Cassandra with capabilities like in-memory computing, enterprise-level security, fast and powerful integrated analytics, and enterprise management.
trans-unit.target: In addition to what the Community edition provides, Datastax Enterprise is Production-certified Cassandra with capabilities like in-memory computing, enterprise-level security, fast and powerful integrated analytics, and enterprise management.

trans-unit.source: Unlike the Community edition, in order to deploy DataStax Enterprise, you need to have a valid DataStax account (username and password) to pass in as parameters during template deployment.
trans-unit.target: Unlike the Community edition, in order to deploy DataStax Enterprise, you need to have a valid DataStax account (username and password) to pass in as parameters during template deployment.

trans-unit.source: Visit the <linkText>Datastax</linkText><title></title> website to set up your account if you don’t have one already.
trans-unit.target: Visit the <linkText>Datastax</linkText><title></title> website to set up your account if you don’t have one already.

trans-unit.source: In addition to what is already available in Azure Marketplace, now you can also easily deploy a new Datastax Enterprise cluster on Ubuntu VMs using a Resource Manager template deployed through <linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> or the <linkText>Azure CLI</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: In addition to what is already available in Azure Marketplace, now you can also easily deploy a new Datastax Enterprise cluster on Ubuntu VMs using a Resource Manager template deployed through <linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> or the <linkText>Azure CLI</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Newly deployed clusters based on this template will have the topology described in the following diagram, although other topologies can be easily achieved by customizing the template presented in this article.
trans-unit.target: Newly deployed clusters based on this template will have the topology described in the following diagram, although other topologies can be easily achieved by customizing the template presented in this article.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>cluster-architecture</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>cluster-architecture</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Using parameters, you can define the number of nodes that will be deployed in the new Apache Cassandra cluster.
trans-unit.target: Using parameters, you can define the number of nodes that will be deployed in the new Apache Cassandra cluster.

trans-unit.source: An instance of the DataStax Operation Center service will be also deployed in a standalone VM within the same VNET, giving you the ability to monitor the status of the cluster and all individual nodes, add/remove nodes, and perform all administrative tasks related to that cluster.
trans-unit.target: An instance of the DataStax Operation Center service will be also deployed in a standalone VM within the same VNET, giving you the ability to monitor the status of the cluster and all individual nodes, add/remove nodes, and perform all administrative tasks related to that cluster.

trans-unit.source: Once the deployment is complete, you can access the Datastax Operations Center VM instance using the configured DNS address.
trans-unit.target: Once the deployment is complete, you can access the Datastax Operations Center VM instance using the configured DNS address.

trans-unit.source: The OpsCenter VM has SSH port 22 enabled, as well as port 8443 for HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: The OpsCenter VM has SSH port 22 enabled, as well as port 8443 for HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: The DNS address for the operations center will include the dnsName and region entered as parameters, resulting in the format {dnsName}.{region}.cloudapp.azure.com.
trans-unit.target: The DNS address for the operations center will include the dnsName and region entered as parameters, resulting in the format {dnsName}.{region}.cloudapp.azure.com.

trans-unit.source: If you created a deployment with the dnsName parameter set to "datastax” in the "West US” region you could access the Datastax Operations Center VM for the deployment at https://datastax.westus.cloudapp.azure.com:8443.
trans-unit.target: If you created a deployment with the dnsName parameter set to "datastax” in the "West US” region you could access the Datastax Operations Center VM for the deployment at https://datastax.westus.cloudapp.azure.com:8443.

trans-unit.source: The certificate used in the deployment is a self-signed certificate that will create a browser warning.
trans-unit.target: The certificate used in the deployment is a self-signed certificate that will create a browser warning.

trans-unit.source: You can follow the process on the <linkText>Datastax</linkText><title></title> web site for replacing the certificate with your own SSL certificate.
trans-unit.target: You can follow the process on the <linkText>Datastax</linkText><title></title> web site for replacing the certificate with your own SSL certificate.

trans-unit.source: Before diving into more details related to the Azure Resource Manager and the template we will use for this deployment, make sure you have Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI configured correctly.
trans-unit.target: Before diving into more details related to the Azure Resource Manager and the template we will use for this deployment, make sure you have Azure PowerShell or the Azure CLI configured correctly.

trans-unit.source: Follow these steps to create an Apache Cassandra cluster, based on DataStax Enterprise, using a Resource Manager template from the Github template repository.
trans-unit.target: Follow these steps to create an Apache Cassandra cluster, based on DataStax Enterprise, using a Resource Manager template from the Github template repository.

trans-unit.source: Each step will include directions for both Azure PowerShell and the Azure CLI.
trans-unit.target: Each step will include directions for both Azure PowerShell and the Azure CLI.

trans-unit.source: Create a local folder for the JSON template and other associated files (for example, C:\Azure\Templates\DataStax).
trans-unit.target: Create a local folder for the JSON template and other associated files (for example, C:\Azure\Templates\DataStax).

trans-unit.source: Substitute in the folder name of your local folder and run the next set of commands.
trans-unit.target: Substitute in the folder name of your local folder and run the next set of commands.

trans-unit.source: Clone the entire template repository using a git client of your choice, as shown in the next example.
trans-unit.target: Clone the entire template repository using a git client of your choice, as shown in the next example.

trans-unit.source: When completed, look for the datastax-enterprise folder in your C:\Azure\Templates directory.
trans-unit.target: When completed, look for the datastax-enterprise folder in your C:\Azure\Templates directory.

trans-unit.source: When you deploy non-trivial solutions like an Apache Cassandra cluster based on DataStax, you must specify a set of configuration parameters to deal with a number of required settings.
trans-unit.target: When you deploy non-trivial solutions like an Apache Cassandra cluster based on DataStax, you must specify a set of configuration parameters to deal with a number of required settings.

trans-unit.source: By declaring these parameters in the template definition, it’s possible to specify values during deployment through an external file or in the command line.
trans-unit.target: By declaring these parameters in the template definition, it’s possible to specify values during deployment through an external file or in the command line.

trans-unit.source: In the "parameters" section at the top of the azuredeploy.json file, you’ll find the set of parameters that are required by the template to configure a Datastax Enterprise cluster.
trans-unit.target: In the "parameters" section at the top of the azuredeploy.json file, you’ll find the set of parameters that are required by the template to configure a Datastax Enterprise cluster.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example of the parameters section from this template's azuredeploy.json file.
trans-unit.target: Here is an example of the parameters section from this template's azuredeploy.json file.

trans-unit.source: Each parameter has details such as data type and allowed values.
trans-unit.target: Each parameter has details such as data type and allowed values.

trans-unit.source: This allows for validation of parameters passed during template execution in an interactive mode (for example, PowerShell or Azure CLI), as well as a self-discovery UI that could be dynamically-built by parsing the list of required parameters and their descriptions.
trans-unit.target: This allows for validation of parameters passed during template execution in an interactive mode (for example, PowerShell or Azure CLI), as well as a self-discovery UI that could be dynamically-built by parsing the list of required parameters and their descriptions.

trans-unit.source: Prepare a parameters file for your deployment by creating a JSON file containing run-time values for all parameters.
trans-unit.target: Prepare a parameters file for your deployment by creating a JSON file containing run-time values for all parameters.

trans-unit.source: This file will then be passed as a single entity to the deployment command.
trans-unit.target: This file will then be passed as a single entity to the deployment command.

trans-unit.source: If you do not include a parameters file, PowerShell will use any default values specified in the template, and then prompt you to fill in the remaining values.
trans-unit.target: If you do not include a parameters file, PowerShell will use any default values specified in the template, and then prompt you to fill in the remaining values.

trans-unit.source: The next example is a set of parameters from the azuredeploy-parameters.json file.
trans-unit.target: The next example is a set of parameters from the azuredeploy-parameters.json file.

trans-unit.source: Fill in an Azure deployment name, resource group name, Azure location, and the folder of your saved JSON deployment file.
trans-unit.target: Fill in an Azure deployment name, resource group name, Azure location, and the folder of your saved JSON deployment file.

trans-unit.source: Then run the next set of commands.
trans-unit.target: Then run the next set of commands.

trans-unit.source: When you run the New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment command, this will extract parameter values from the JSON parameters file, and will start executing the template accordingly.
trans-unit.target: When you run the New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment command, this will extract parameter values from the JSON parameters file, and will start executing the template accordingly.

trans-unit.source: Defining and using multiple parameter files with your different environments (for example, Test, or Production) will promote template reuse and simplify complex multi-environment solutions.
trans-unit.target: Defining and using multiple parameter files with your different environments (for example, Test, or Production) will promote template reuse and simplify complex multi-environment solutions.

trans-unit.source: When deploying, keep in mind that a new Azure Storage Account needs to be created so the name you provide as the storage account parameter must be unique and meet all requirements for an Azure Storage Account (lowercase letters and numbers only).
trans-unit.target: When deploying, keep in mind that a new Azure Storage Account needs to be created so the name you provide as the storage account parameter must be unique and meet all requirements for an Azure Storage Account (lowercase letters and numbers only).

trans-unit.source: During and after deployment, you can check all the requests that were made during provisioning, including any errors that occurred.
trans-unit.target: During and after deployment, you can check all the requests that were made during provisioning, including any errors that occurred.

trans-unit.source: To do that, go to the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title> and do the following:
trans-unit.target: To do that, go to the <linkText>Azure Portal</linkText><title></title> and do the following:

trans-unit.source: Click "Browse” on the left-hand navigation bar, scroll down and click "Resource Groups”.
trans-unit.target: Click "Browse” on the left-hand navigation bar, scroll down and click "Resource Groups”.

trans-unit.source: After clicking the Resource Group that you just created, it will bring up the "Resource Group” blade.
trans-unit.target: After clicking the Resource Group that you just created, it will bring up the "Resource Group” blade.

trans-unit.source: By clicking the "Events” bar graph in the "Monitoring” part of the "Resource Group” blade, you can see the events for your deployment:
trans-unit.target: By clicking the "Events” bar graph in the "Monitoring” part of the "Resource Group” blade, you can see the events for your deployment:

trans-unit.source: Clicking individual events lets you drill further down into the details of each individual operation made on behalf of the template.
trans-unit.target: Clicking individual events lets you drill further down into the details of each individual operation made on behalf of the template.

trans-unit.source: After your tests, if you need to remove this resource group and all of its resources (the storage account, virtual machine, and virtual network), use the next command.
trans-unit.target: After your tests, if you need to remove this resource group and all of its resources (the storage account, virtual machine, and virtual network), use the next command.

trans-unit.source: To deploy a Datastax Enterprise cluster via the Azure CLI, first create a Resource Group by specifying a name and a location with the next command.
trans-unit.target: To deploy a Datastax Enterprise cluster via the Azure CLI, first create a Resource Group by specifying a name and a location with the next command.

trans-unit.source: Pass this Resource Group name, the location of the JSON template file, and the location of the parameters file (see the above PowerShell section for details) into the following command.
trans-unit.target: Pass this Resource Group name, the location of the JSON template file, and the location of the parameters file (see the above PowerShell section for details) into the following command.

trans-unit.source: You can check the status of individual resources deployments with the following command.
trans-unit.target: You can check the status of individual resources deployments with the following command.

trans-unit.source: In order to design a robust and reusable Resource Manager template, additional thinking is needed to organize the series of complex and interrelated tasks required during the deployment of a complex solution like DataStax Enterprise.
trans-unit.target: In order to design a robust and reusable Resource Manager template, additional thinking is needed to organize the series of complex and interrelated tasks required during the deployment of a complex solution like DataStax Enterprise.

trans-unit.source: Leveraging ARM template linking and resource looping in addition to script execution through related extensions, it’s possible to implement a modular approach that can be reused with virtually any complex template-based deployment.
trans-unit.target: Leveraging ARM template linking and resource looping in addition to script execution through related extensions, it’s possible to implement a modular approach that can be reused with virtually any complex template-based deployment.

trans-unit.source: The next diagram describes the relationships between all the files downloaded from GitHub for this deployment.
trans-unit.target: The next diagram describes the relationships between all the files downloaded from GitHub for this deployment.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>datastax-enterprise-files</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>datastax-enterprise-files</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This section steps you through the structure of the azuredeploy.json file for the Datastax Enterprise cluster.
trans-unit.target: This section steps you through the structure of the azuredeploy.json file for the Datastax Enterprise cluster.

trans-unit.source: The "parameters" section of azuredeploy.json specifies modifiable parameters that are used in this template.
trans-unit.target: The "parameters" section of azuredeploy.json specifies modifiable parameters that are used in this template.

trans-unit.source: The previously mentioned azuredeploy-parameters.json file is used to pass values into the "parameters" section of azuredeploy.json during template execution.
trans-unit.target: The previously mentioned azuredeploy-parameters.json file is used to pass values into the "parameters" section of azuredeploy.json during template execution.

trans-unit.source: The "variables" section specifies variables that can be used throughout this template.
trans-unit.target: The "variables" section specifies variables that can be used throughout this template.

trans-unit.source: This contains a number of fields (JSON data types or fragments) that will be set to constants or calculated values at execution time.
trans-unit.target: This contains a number of fields (JSON data types or fragments) that will be set to constants or calculated values at execution time.

trans-unit.source: The next example shows the "variables" section for this Datastax template.
trans-unit.target: The next example shows the "variables" section for this Datastax template.

trans-unit.source: In the previous example, you can see two different approaches.
trans-unit.target: In the previous example, you can see two different approaches.

trans-unit.source: In the first fragment, the "osSettings” variable is a nested JSON element containing 4 key-value pairs.
trans-unit.target: In the first fragment, the "osSettings” variable is a nested JSON element containing 4 key-value pairs.

trans-unit.source: The "resources" section is where most of the action is happening.
trans-unit.target: The "resources" section is where most of the action is happening.

trans-unit.source: Looking inside this section, you can immediately identify two different cases: the first one is an element defined of type Microsoft.Resources/deployments that basically means the invocation of a nested deployment within the main one.
trans-unit.target: Looking inside this section, you can immediately identify two different cases: the first one is an element defined of type Microsoft.Resources/deployments that basically means the invocation of a nested deployment within the main one.

trans-unit.source: Through the "templateLink" element (and related version property), it’s possible to specify a linked template file that will be invoked by passing a set of parameters as input, as shown in the next example.
trans-unit.target: Through the "templateLink" element (and related version property), it’s possible to specify a linked template file that will be invoked by passing a set of parameters as input, as shown in the next example.

trans-unit.source: From this first example, it is clear how azuredeploy.json in this scenario has been organized as a sort of orchestration mechanism, invoking a number of other template files, each one responsible for part of the required deployment activities.
trans-unit.target: From this first example, it is clear how azuredeploy.json in this scenario has been organized as a sort of orchestration mechanism, invoking a number of other template files, each one responsible for part of the required deployment activities.

trans-unit.source: In particular, the following linked templates will be used for this deployment:
trans-unit.target: In particular, the following linked templates will be used for this deployment:

trans-unit.source: shared-resource.json: Contains the definition of all resources that will be shared across the deployment.
trans-unit.target: shared-resource.json: Contains the definition of all resources that will be shared across the deployment.

trans-unit.source: Examples are storage accounts used to store VM’s OS disks and virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: Examples are storage accounts used to store VM’s OS disks and virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: opscenter-resources.json: Deploys an OpsCenter VM and all related resources, including a network interface and public IP address.
trans-unit.target: opscenter-resources.json: Deploys an OpsCenter VM and all related resources, including a network interface and public IP address.

trans-unit.source: opscenter-install-resources.json: Deploys the OpsCenter VM extension (custom script for Linux) that will invoke the specific bash script file (opscenter.sh) required to set up the OpsCenter service within that VM.
trans-unit.target: opscenter-install-resources.json: Deploys the OpsCenter VM extension (custom script for Linux) that will invoke the specific bash script file (opscenter.sh) required to set up the OpsCenter service within that VM.

trans-unit.source: ephemeral-nodes-resources.json: Deploys all cluster node VMs and connected resources (for example, network cards, and private IPs.).
trans-unit.target: ephemeral-nodes-resources.json: Deploys all cluster node VMs and connected resources (for example, network cards, and private IPs.).

trans-unit.source: This template will also deploy VM extensions (custom scripts for Linux) and invoke a bash script (dsenode.sh) to physically install Apache Cassandra bits on each node.
trans-unit.target: This template will also deploy VM extensions (custom scripts for Linux) and invoke a bash script (dsenode.sh) to physically install Apache Cassandra bits on each node.

trans-unit.source: Let’s drill down into how this last template is used, as it is one of the most interesting from a template development perspective.
trans-unit.target: Let’s drill down into how this last template is used, as it is one of the most interesting from a template development perspective.

trans-unit.source: One important concept to highlight is how a single template file can deploy multiple copies of a single resource type, and for each instance can set unique values for required settings.
trans-unit.target: One important concept to highlight is how a single template file can deploy multiple copies of a single resource type, and for each instance can set unique values for required settings.

trans-unit.source: This concept is known as Resource Looping.
trans-unit.target: This concept is known as Resource Looping.

trans-unit.source: When ephemeral-nodes-resources.json is invoked from within the main azuredeploy.json file, a parameter called nodeCount is provided as part of the parameters list.
trans-unit.target: When ephemeral-nodes-resources.json is invoked from within the main azuredeploy.json file, a parameter called nodeCount is provided as part of the parameters list.

trans-unit.source: Within the child template, nodeCount (the number of nodes to deploy in the cluster) will be used inside the "copy” element of each resource that needs to be deployed in multiple copies, as highlighted in the next example.
trans-unit.target: Within the child template, nodeCount (the number of nodes to deploy in the cluster) will be used inside the "copy” element of each resource that needs to be deployed in multiple copies, as highlighted in the next example.

trans-unit.source: For all settings where you need unique values for different instances of the deployed resource, the copyindex() function can be used to obtain a numeric value indicating the current index in that particular resource loop creation.
trans-unit.target: For all settings where you need unique values for different instances of the deployed resource, the copyindex() function can be used to obtain a numeric value indicating the current index in that particular resource loop creation.

trans-unit.source: In the next example, you can see this concept applied to multiple VMs being created for the Datastax Enterprise cluster nodes.
trans-unit.target: In the next example, you can see this concept applied to multiple VMs being created for the Datastax Enterprise cluster nodes.

trans-unit.source: Another important concept in resource creation is the ability to specify dependencies and precedencies between resources, as you can see in the dependsOn JSON array.
trans-unit.target: Another important concept in resource creation is the ability to specify dependencies and precedencies between resources, as you can see in the dependsOn JSON array.

trans-unit.source: In this particular template, each node will also have an attached 1 TB disk (see "dataDisks") that can be used for hosting backups and snapshots of the Apache Cassandra instance.
trans-unit.target: In this particular template, each node will also have an attached 1 TB disk (see "dataDisks") that can be used for hosting backups and snapshots of the Apache Cassandra instance.

trans-unit.source: Attached disks are formatted as part of the node preparation activities triggered by the execution of the dsenode.sh script file.
trans-unit.target: Attached disks are formatted as part of the node preparation activities triggered by the execution of the dsenode.sh script file.

trans-unit.source: In the next example, the first row of that script invokes another script.
trans-unit.target: In the next example, the first row of that script invokes another script.

trans-unit.source: vm-disk-utils-0.1.sh is part of the shared_scripts\ubuntu folder in the azure-quickstart-tempates github repo, and contains very useful functions for disk mounting, formatting, and striping.
trans-unit.target: vm-disk-utils-0.1.sh is part of the shared_scripts\ubuntu folder in the azure-quickstart-tempates github repo, and contains very useful functions for disk mounting, formatting, and striping.

trans-unit.source: These functions can be used in all templates in the repo.
trans-unit.target: These functions can be used in all templates in the repo.

trans-unit.source: Another interesting fragment to explore is the one related to CustomScriptForLinux VM extensions.
trans-unit.target: Another interesting fragment to explore is the one related to CustomScriptForLinux VM extensions.

trans-unit.source: These are installed as a separate type of resource, with a dependency on each cluster node (and the OpsCenter instance).
trans-unit.target: These are installed as a separate type of resource, with a dependency on each cluster node (and the OpsCenter instance).

trans-unit.source: They leverage the same resource looping mechanism described for virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: They leverage the same resource looping mechanism described for virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: By familiarizing yourself with the other files included in this deployment, you will be able to understand all the details and best practices required to organize and orchestrate complex deployment strategies for multi-nodes solutions, based on any technology, leveraging Azure Resource Manager templates.
trans-unit.target: By familiarizing yourself with the other files included in this deployment, you will be able to understand all the details and best practices required to organize and orchestrate complex deployment strategies for multi-nodes solutions, based on any technology, leveraging Azure Resource Manager templates.

trans-unit.source: While not mandatory, a recommended approach is to structure your template files as shown in the following diagram.
trans-unit.target: While not mandatory, a recommended approach is to structure your template files as shown in the following diagram.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>datastax-enterprise-template-structure</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>datastax-enterprise-template-structure</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This approach suggests that you:
trans-unit.target: This approach suggests that you:

trans-unit.source: Define your core template file as a central orchestration point for all specific deployment activities, leveraging template linking to invoke sub template executions.
trans-unit.target: Define your core template file as a central orchestration point for all specific deployment activities, leveraging template linking to invoke sub template executions.

trans-unit.source: Create a specific template file that will deploy all resources shared across all other specific deployment tasks (for example, storage accounts, and vnet configuration).
trans-unit.target: Create a specific template file that will deploy all resources shared across all other specific deployment tasks (for example, storage accounts, and vnet configuration).

trans-unit.source: This can be heavily reused between deployments that have similar requirements in terms of common infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: This can be heavily reused between deployments that have similar requirements in terms of common infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: Include optional resource templates for spot requirements specific of a given resource.
trans-unit.target: Include optional resource templates for spot requirements specific of a given resource.

trans-unit.source: For identical members of a group of resources (for example, nodes in a cluster) create specific templates that leverage resource looping in order to deploy multiple instances with unique properties.
trans-unit.target: For identical members of a group of resources (for example, nodes in a cluster) create specific templates that leverage resource looping in order to deploy multiple instances with unique properties.

trans-unit.source: For all post deployment tasks (for example, product installation,and configurations) leverage script deployment extensions and create scripts specific to each technology.
trans-unit.target: For all post deployment tasks (for example, product installation,and configurations) leverage script deployment extensions and create scripts specific to each technology.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Template Language</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Template Language</linkText><title></title>.
